newsitem.title: UK: UK Building Socs Bill doubtful starter - minister.
newsitem.headline: UK Building Socs Bill doubtful starter - minister.

text.p: The Building Societies Bill, which would allow the institutions to engage in a wider range of activities, could well not pass into law before the next general election, a government minister said on Thursday.
"I certainly would not suggest that it is a racing likelihood," the minister, who declined to be identified, said.

He said the government had already agreed to add a number of bills to its legislative programme for the current session of parliament, which must be curtailed because a general election is due by May 22.
It was therefore doubtful whether sufficient time could be found to discuss the provisions of the Building Society Bill, he said.
Addressing a Building Societies Association meeting earlier on Thursday, economic secretary to the Treasury Angela Knight said she could not promise the Bill would get parliamentary time.

But she went on: "What I can promise you, though, is if you, the industry, decide that you want this Bill, then that vastly strengthens my hand and I will do everything I can to get your Bill that time in the legislative programme."
Mike O'Brien, an economics spokesman for the opposition Labour Party, said he had asked for a meeting with Knight to discuss the Bill.
"The Government seem to have decided to revive the Bill without giving it parliamentary time," he said. -- London Newsroom +44 171 5427767
